test_patch:
diff --git a/test/sql/alter/alter_type/test_alter_type_incorrect.test b/test/sql/alter/alter_type/test_alter_type_incorrect.test
index 2e6ff465e066..42c042c7472a 100644
--- a/test/sql/alter/alter_type/test_alter_type_incorrect.test
+++ b/test/sql/alter/alter_type/test_alter_type_incorrect.test
@@ -23,3 +23,6 @@ ALTER TABLE test ALTER i SET TYPE VARCHAR USING SUM(i)
 statement error
 ALTER TABLE test ALTER i SET TYPE VARCHAR USING row_id() OVER ()
 
+statement error
+ALTER TABLE test ALTER i SET TYPE VARCHAR USING othertable.j
+
diff --git a/test/sql/binder/test_case_insensitive_binding.test b/test/sql/binder/test_case_insensitive_binding.test
index 43aa901a00c8..bfc47ab8db72 100644
--- a/test/sql/binder/test_case_insensitive_binding.test
+++ b/test/sql/binder/test_case_insensitive_binding.test
@@ -23,11 +23,10 @@ SELECT hello FROM test
 statement ok
 SELECT "HeLlO" FROM test
 
-# specifying a different, non-lower, case does fail!
-statement error
+statement ok
 SELECT "HELLO" FROM test
 
-statement error
+statement ok
 SELECT "HELLo" FROM test
 
 # verify that the column name of the original column is returned
@@ -57,10 +56,10 @@ SELECT test.hello FROM test
 statement ok
 SELECT test."HeLlO" FROM test
 
-statement error
+statement ok
 SELECT test."HELLO" FROM test
 
-statement error
+statement ok
 SELECT test."HELLo" FROM test
 
 statement ok
@@ -128,10 +127,10 @@ SELECT HeLlO FROM test1, test2
 statement error
 SELECT hello FROM test1, test2
 
-statement ok
+statement error
 SELECT "HeLlO" FROM test1, test2
 
-statement ok
+statement error
 SELECT "HELLO" FROM test1, test2
 
 statement error
@@ -147,10 +146,10 @@ SELECT test1.hello FROM test1, test2
 statement ok
 SELECT test1."HeLlO" FROM test1, test2
 
-statement error
+statement ok
 SELECT test1."HELLO" FROM test1, test2
 
-statement error
+statement ok
 SELECT test1."HELLo" FROM test1, test2
 
 statement ok
@@ -159,13 +158,13 @@ SELECT test2.HeLlO FROM test1, test2
 statement ok
 SELECT test2.hello FROM test1, test2
 
-statement error
+statement ok
 SELECT test2."HeLlO" FROM test1, test2
 
 statement ok
 SELECT test2."HELLO" FROM test1, test2
 
-statement error
+statement ok
 SELECT test2."HELLo" FROM test1, test2
 
 statement ok
diff --git a/test/sql/catalog/case_insensitive_alter.test b/test/sql/catalog/case_insensitive_alter.test
new file mode 100644
index 000000000000..860fbfabef34
--- /dev/null
+++ b/test/sql/catalog/case_insensitive_alter.test
@@ -0,0 +1,41 @@
+# name: test/sql/catalog/case_insensitive_alter.test
+# description: Test case insensitive alter
+# group: [catalog]
+
+statement ok
+CREATE TABLE "MyTable"(i integer, "BigColumn" integer);
+
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE MyTable ALTER BIGCOLUMN SET DATA TYPE VARCHAR
+
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE MyTable DROP COLUMN BIGCOLUMN;
+
+statement error
+SELECT BIGCOLUMN FROM MyTable
+
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE MyTable ADD COLUMN "BIGCOLUMN" VARCHAR;
+
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE MyTable ALTER COLUMN BIGCOLUMN SET DEFAULT 3
+
+statement ok
+INSERT INTO MyTable(BIGCOLUMN) VALUES (DEFAULT)
+
+query I
+SELECT BIGCOLUMN FROM MyTable
+----
+3
+
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE MyTable ALTER COLUMN BIGCOLUMN DROP DEFAULT
+
+statement ok
+SELECT BIGCOLUMN FROM MyTable
+
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE MyTable RENAME BIGCOLUMN TO "SmallColumn"
+
+statement ok
+SELECT SmallColumn FROM MyTable
diff --git a/test/sql/catalog/case_insensitive_caps.test b/test/sql/catalog/case_insensitive_caps.test
new file mode 100644
index 000000000000..3dbf138d4bf5
--- /dev/null
+++ b/test/sql/catalog/case_insensitive_caps.test
@@ -0,0 +1,24 @@
+# name: test/sql/catalog/case_insensitive_caps.test
+# description: Test case insensitivity with quoted values
+# group: [catalog]
+
+# we create a table in lowercase names
+statement ok
+CREATE TABLE mytable(mycolumn INTEGER, myothercolumn INTEGER);
+
+# we can query the column using quoted text
+statement ok
+SELECT "MYCOLUMN" FROM "MYTABLE";
+
+# we can also alter in this manner
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE "MYTABLE" DROP COLUMN "MYCOLUMN";
+
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE "MYTABLE" ADD COLUMN mycolumn INTEGER;
+
+statement ok
+ALTER TABLE "MYTABLE" ALTER COLUMN "MYCOLUMN" SET DEFAULT 3
+
+statement ok
+DROP TABLE "MYTABLE"
problem_statement:
Unable to drop column
If you try to drop column from the table which has been created from CSV-file you will get a Catalog error.

```
D CREATE TABLE ontime AS SELECT * FROM read_csv_auto('test.csv');
D DESCRIBE ontime;
┌────────────────┬─────────┬──────┬─────┬─────────┬───────┐
│     Field      │  Type   │ Null │ Key │ Default │ Extra │
├────────────────┼─────────┼──────┼─────┼─────────┼───────┤
│ FlightDate     │ DATE    │ YES  │     │         │       │
│ UniqueCarrier  │ VARCHAR │ YES  │     │         │       │
│ OriginCityName │ VARCHAR │ YES  │     │         │       │
│ DestCityName   │ VARCHAR │ YES  │     │         │       │
└────────────────┴─────────┴──────┴─────┴─────────┴───────┘
D ALTER TABLE ontime DROP FlighDate;
Error: Catalog Error: Table does not have a column with name "flighdate"

```
This is happening on Windows with client 0.2.7
hints_text:
You have to use quotation marks. ;) Sorry!
Thanks for opening the issue! We try to avoid case-sensitivity when not required. While indeed you can solve this using quotation marks (and you would need to in other systems), I will re-open this since we want the unquoted variant to also work here.
